title: Makes provisions on imposition of surcharges on certain bridges and tunnels
summary: Prohibits a toll increase on tolls for bridges and tunnels subject to the jurisdiction of the Triborough bridge and tunnel authority; allows the authority to impose a surcharge in addition to the regular toll; increases the amount of annual surplus to be transferred by the Triborough bridge and tunnel authority to the New York city transit authority.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2673

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the public authorities law, in relation to the imposition
of tolls and surcharges for certain bridges and tunnels

SUMMARY:
This legislation amends the public
authorities law by adding a new section 553-h-1
to prohibit an increase in the toll surcharge on all
bridges and tunnels operated by the Triborough Bridge and Tunnel
Authority (TBTA).

JUSTIFICATION:
During these times of recession, an
increase in a
surcharge in tolls is forcing the middle class to leave the city. It
is economically unwise to force the working people of the city, the
backbone of our economy to relocate. Furthermore, the increased tolls
(tax) collected from these same people, would be used by the MTA. The
MTA justifies this increase as a method to help rectify the budgetary
problems and prevent a fare increase. This argument avoids the real
issue. The current apportionment of TBTA toll funds favors the
commuter rail lines which operate with a monetary surplus each year.
This allocation formula operates at the direct expense of the MTA
subways and buses which need the most work and operate at a financial
defeat. This situation is compounded in its unfairness by the fact
that most of these funds are used to support rail systems that
provide almost no service to city residents. Therefore, the real
issue is the funding formula of excess TBTA tolls. This bill
reallocates those funds and gives the NYC MTA its fair share, while
holding back toll increases. Automobile owners already pay high
registration fees and taxes on gasoline in addition to the many taxes
they pay for the privilege of living in our
city. While these burdens increase, there seems to be no reciprocal
increase in available services. For many, mass transit is not a
viable option, and they must rely on their cars. To increase tolls on
these facilities is unfair punishment to the middle class who
regularly must bear the brunt of our government's failures. Levying
unnecessary taxes on this group of New Yorkers will eventually lead
them to leave our city, further compounding our fiscal peril. The
government should work to reverse this trend, not to contribute to it.

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
None.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect immediately.
